title: Change of Condition — Critical Labs (Decision Support)
summary: A triage workflow for critical/panic lab values in LTC/SNF: immediate safety checks, focused assessment, SBAR notification, and packet-ready documentation.

sections.heading: Scope and safety note
sections.body: Critical value thresholds vary by lab and facility policy. Use this as decision-support: verify the result, assess the resident, and notify the provider per protocol. Escalate to a higher level of care when clinically indicated or directed by the provider.

sections.heading: First 5 minutes checklist (any critical lab)
sections.body: Verify the report (resident, date/time). Assess ABCs and symptoms. Obtain vital signs and compare to baseline. Review current meds/recent changes (diuretics, insulin, ACE/ARB, potassium supplements, anticoagulants). Notify provider using SBAR with objective data. Document: notifications, orders received, interventions, response, monitoring/escalation plan.

sections.heading: Example: Potassium 2.5 mmol/L (severe hypokalemia)
sections.body: Treat K=2.5 mmol/L as a critical/urgent result. Evaluate for weakness/cramps, palpitations, dizziness/syncope, and hydration/GI losses (vomiting/diarrhea). Review contributing meds (diuretics, insulin, beta-agonists, laxatives) and consider concurrent low magnesium. Obtain vitals and monitor for arrhythmia symptoms; obtain EKG/telemetry if available/ordered. Notify provider promptly with SBAR; anticipate repeat labs and replacement orders per provider. Escalate to ED if symptomatic, unstable vitals, suspected arrhythmia, or unable to manage safely in facility per policy/provider direction.

sections.heading: Common critical labs to include in the wizard
sections.body: Common 'call/critical' labs used by many labs include: Potassium, Sodium, Glucose, Calcium (total/ionized), Magnesium, Phosphorus, Lactate, Hemoglobin/Hematocrit, Platelets, WBC/ANC, and INR. Use your contracted lab’s published critical value table as the facility-specific source of truth.
